title: Japan's Renewable Energy Goals and U.S. Emissions Trends in 2024
summary:
- Japan aims for renewables to make up 40-50% of its energy mix by fiscal 2040, increasing from 36-38% for 2030.
- The energy plan allocates 30-40% to thermal power and about 20% to nuclear energy, promoting next-generation nuclear reactors.
- The strategy addresses rising electricity demand, driven by AI, while ensuring energy stability and lower carbon emissions, without reducing reliance on nuclear power.
- The U.S. invested a record-breaking $338 billion in energy transition in 2024, but carbon emissions slightly increased by 0.5%.
- Solar energy added 49 gigawatts of new capacity, making it the leading technology in the U.S. renewable sector.
- Increased demand for natural gas, particularly from industrial users and power plants, contributed to the rise in carbon emissions.
- Electricity demand in the U.S. is projected to increase by 15.8% by 2029, mainly driven by data centers.
- Tech companies are investing in nuclear power and renewable sources to meet rising energy needs, with Amazon and Meta making significant agreements for additional solar capacity.

title: Your Android phone could have stalkerware. Here’s how to remove it
summary:
- Consumer-grade spyware apps can monitor private messages, photos, calls, and location on Android devices.
- This guide helps identify and remove stalkerware such as [TheTruthSpy](https://techcrunch.com/2022/10/26/inside-thetruthspy-stalkerware/), [Cocospy](https://techcrunch.com/2025/02/20/stalkerware-apps-cocospy-spyic-exposing-phone-data-of-millions-of-people/), and [Spyic](https://techcrunch.com/2025/02/20/stalkerware-apps-cocospy-spyic-exposing-phone-data-of-millions-of-people/).
- Stalkerware is disguised as child monitoring or family-tracking software, often installed without consent.
- Possible signs of infection include unusual phone behavior, excessive data use, and performance issues.
- Key steps to mitigate stalkerware include enabling [Google Play Protect](https://techcrunch.com/2023/11/04/google-play-android-real-time-app-scanning-sideload-apps/), checking accessibility services, and reviewing notification access settings.

sources.title: Your Android phone could have stalkerware. Here’s how to remove it

title: Hacked, leaked, exposed: Why you should never use stalkerware apps
summary:

- Cocospy and Spyic leaked 2.65 million customer email addresses and various personal data.
- Several high-profile breaches have occurred, including those of mSpy and pcTattletale, leading to widespread data exposure.
- Experts highlight that stalkerware apps are a risky choice due to the dangerous implications for victims and the untrustworthiness of the companies behind them.

title: Stalkerware apps Cocospy and Spyic are exposing phone data of millions of people
summary:
- A security vulnerability in Cocospy and Spyic, phone-monitoring apps, exposes personal data of millions.  
- The vulnerability allows access to messages, photos, call logs, and email addresses of users.  
- The researcher collected over 2.65 million unique email addresses from both apps, marking the data as sensitive in Have I Been Pwned.  
- The apps, marketed for parental control and employee monitoring, are often used for spying without consent and are banned from app stores.  
- Cocospy launched in 2018 and Spyic in 2019, with evidence linking their operations to a China-based developer.  
- Users can check for the apps on their devices using specific codes and should enable security settings to protect against such vulnerabilities.

title: Researchers say new attack could take down the European power grid
summary:
- Researchers discovered that renewable energy facilities in Central Europe use unencrypted radio signals for controlling power grid input and output.
- The system allows for the control of approximately 60 GW of energy, including both generation and load management.
- An optimally crafted series of messages could theoretically disable the entire European power grid, a potential risk they highlighted at the 38th Chaos Communication Congress.
- The communication protocol utilized is called Radio Ripple Control, which is based on an older protocol dating back to the early 1900s.
- No encryption is applied to the signals, allowing unauthorized users to intercept and manipulate them.

sources.title: Researchers say new attack could take down the European power grid

- The home button was crucial for early smartphone users and evolved to include features like Siri access and Touch ID.
- The decision to remove the home button reflects the trend toward modern, full-screen smartphone designs.
- While users have adapted to new navigation methods, the legacy of the home button in smartphone innovation will be remembered.

title: Meta settles Israeli privacy lawsuit for $338k

title: Concerns Rise as Paragon Solutions Spyware Targets Activists and Journalists amid Mollitiam Industries Shutdown
summary:

- Incident exemplifies escalating cybersecurity threats towards journalism and activism.
- WhatsApp intervened to disrupt Paragon's hacking activities to safeguard users.

- Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni’s office distanced itself from claims regarding the spyware use.

- Mollitiam Industries, a Spanish spyware entity, is closing due to financial struggles, filing for bankruptcy on January 23, 2025.
- Known products include Invisible Man and Night Crawler; the company had 11 to 50 employees.
- Mollitiam's involvement in surveillance controversies, including cases in Colombia against journalists, is noted.
- Activity continued until the end of 2023, under watch by organizations like Amnesty International.

title: 8 important things to know about the iPhone 16E + Apple discontinues the iPhone 14
summary:
- Apple has stopped selling the iPhone 14, which was first released in 2022.
- The device disappeared from Apple's website after the launch of the iPhone 16E.
- The iPhone 14 was removed from the website’s navigation bar, and selecting it redirects to the iPhone homepage.
- The iPhone 16E starts at the same price of $599, offering upgrades like an A18 chip and a USB-C port.
- Apple began pulling the iPhone 14 from several European online stores due to new EU regulations enforcing USB-C ports.
- Apple announced the iPhone 16E with a starting price of $599, making it the most affordable in the iPhone lineup.
- The iPhone 16E is eSIM-only in the U.S., eliminating physical SIM card support.
- The phone has transitioned from Lightning to USB-C for charging and data transfer, limited to USB 2 speeds.
- MagSafe is not included, and while it supports wireless charging, magnetic accessory compatibility is absent.
- Features a customizable Action Button, similar to the iPhone 15 Pro.
- First iPhone to use Apple’s own C1 modem, promising improved battery life, though performance comparison to Qualcomm is pending.
- The camera offers a 48-megapixel Fusion camera but does not support macro photography.
- Upgrading to 512GB storage will cost an additional $300, bringing the total to $899.
- The display is capped at 60Hz refresh rate.
- Preorders start this Friday, with a release date on February 28th.

sources.title: Apple discontinues the iPhone 14
8 important things to know about the iPhone 16E

title: The Internet is (once again) awash with IoT botnets delivering record DDoSes
summary:
- 2025 is witnessing a surge in IoT-driven DDoS attacks, infecting thousands of devices like routers and webcams.
- Cloudflare reported a DDoS attack reaching 5.6 terabits per second, setting a new record, with 13,000 IoT devices involved.
- Qualys has identified the Murdoc Botnet exploiting vulnerabilities to install Mirai variants on specific cameras and routers, with compromised devices rapidly increasing.
- Trend Micro revealed an IoT botnet using Mirai and Bashlite variants attacking mainly in Japan since late 2024.
- Infoblox reported another botnet with 13,000 MikroTik routers, primarily sending malicious spam emails.

sources.title: The Internet is (once again) awash with IoT botnets delivering record DDoSes

title: iPhone 16E: all the news on Apple’s new $599 phone + Apple’s first in-house iPhone modem is the C1
summary:
- Apple introduced the iPhone 16E, which features the new in-house 5G modem, C1.
- The C1 is touted as the most power-efficient modem and aims to reduce dependency on Qualcomm chips.
- The iPhone 16E will offer up to 26 hours of video playback, thanks to a larger battery design.
- The modem supports much of the same low-end 5G spectrum as the iPhone 16, but lacks mmWave capabilities.
- Preorders for the iPhone 16E start tomorrow, with shipping scheduled for February 28th.
- Apple introduced the iPhone 16E, a successor to the iPhone SE, featuring a new design with Face ID and a notch.
- It is powered by Apple's A18 chip and comes equipped with the new C1 5G modem, claimed to be the most power-efficient modulator.
- The iPhone 16E has a 6.06-inch OLED display, customizable Action Button, USB-C port, no MagSafe support, and a single 48MP rear camera.
- Preorders start on February 21st, 2025, with a launch date set for February 28th, and prices starting at $599.

title: Google Launches Circle to Search-like Feature for iPhone Users
summary:
- Google is introducing a new search feature for iPhone users in the Google app and Chrome browser, allowing them to highlight items on the screen for quick searches.
- The Lens gestures enable searches across text, images, and videos without needing screenshots or new tabs.
- This feature resembles Android’s Circle to Search, although iOS limitations restrict it to Google apps.
- Users can activate it via the three-dot menu and are encouraged to use intuitive gestures to highlight for searches.
- Upcoming updates will add a Lens icon to the address bar for quicker access.
- The feature supports refining searches by color, brand, and allows follow-up questions for more information.
- The update will be rolled out globally this week for iOS users.

summary:

title: My dad died a year ago – and a photo of him on Google Street View brought me up short + Meta AI and Google Gemini Enhance User Interaction with Memory Features
summary:

- Launching the recall feature for English-speaking subscribers of Google One AI Premium at $20/month.
- Users can manage their chat history, including deletion and recall capabilities, addressing privacy concerns.

- Meta is launching a memory feature for its AI chatbot to remember user details like dietary preferences and interests.
- The feature will be available across Facebook, Messenger, and WhatsApp in the US and Canada on both iOS and Android.
- The AI will adjust its responses based on user preferences and past conversations, enhancing personalization.
- Users can manage memories in one-on-one chats, with the ability to delete memories anytime.
- Similar memory functionalities exist in [chatbots](https://www.theverge.com/2025/1/27/24352992/meta-ai-memory-personalization) like ChatGPT and Google Gemini.

- An old friend sent a Google Street View image showing the author’s childhood homes and his late father standing nearby.
- The father passed away a year prior, and the photo resurfaces feelings of love, surprise, and annoyance over privacy concerns with Google.
- The author reflects on the implications of having personal memories shared publicly and the loss of control over how memories are accessed in the digital age.

summary:

- This procurement raises concerns over conflicts of interest as Elon Musk benefits from government contracts.
- Contract award is expected by the end of September, with a document modified to remove Tesla's name from one reference.
- The Tesla Cybertruck received a 5-star crash rating from NHTSA, scoring high in frontal and side crash tests.
- Tesla marketing presents the Cybertruck as the best-selling electric pickup in 2024, despite offering discounts of $1,600 to $2,600 amid demand concerns.
- The Cybertruck has faced multiple recalls, including a recent one for a potential inverter issue.

title: Microsoft announces breakthrough in quantum computing with Majorana 1 chip.
summary:
- Microsoft unveils the Majorana 1 processor after 17 years of research.
- The chip may house a million qubits using Majorana particles for processing.
- Introduction of the world’s first topoconductor for stable qubit control.
- A peer-reviewed study in *Nature* details a topological qubit made from indium arsenide and aluminum.
- DARPA selects Microsoft to create a fault-tolerant quantum computer prototype.
- The goal is to develop a million-qubit system to tackle global challenges.
- The Majorana 1 chip could accelerate quantum computing developments within years.
- Experts are optimistic yet caution against the complexities of viable quantum systems.

title: The Cybertruck is the latest Tesla to score a 5-star crash rating
summary:
- The Tesla Cybertruck received a 5-star crash safety rating from NHTSA after deliveries began in November 2023.
- The vehicle scored 5 stars in most categories including frontal, side crashes, and rollover risk.
- Driver seat center airbag deployed; knee airbags did not deploy during testing due to design specifications.
- In the side crash test, it earned an overall 5-star rating, and a 4-star rating for rollover risk with a 12.4% risk of rollover.
- Tesla conducted its own crash tests, but this is the first independent evaluation by regulators.
- Previously, other Tesla models (Model Y, Model 3, Model X, Model S) also achieved 5-star ratings.
- There are concerns about the Cybertruck's unique design affecting pedestrian safety; no pedestrian safety rating provided in NHTSA's evaluation.
- The Cybertruck has had seven recalls, addressing issues like the rear camera display and faulty windshield wipers.
- Sales have slowed down, prompting Tesla to offer discounts to boost demand.

sources.title: The Cybertruck is the latest Tesla to score a 5-star crash rating

title: Microsoft Unveils AI Model Muse for Xbox and Examines Impact on Critical Thinking
summary:
- Researchers from Microsoft and Carnegie Mellon University published a study on the effects of generative AI on critical thinking skills.
- The paper warns that overreliance on AI may deteriorate cognitive faculties by shifting focus from higher-order thinking to verification of AI outputs.
- In a study of 319 participants using AI weekly, 36% reported utilizing critical thinking skills to counter AI shortcomings.
- Participants often verified AI outputs with external sources, undermining the AI's utility.
- Confident users of AI tended to use less critical thinking than those confident in their own abilities.
- Researchers suggest that while AI tools don't make users dumber, they can weaken problem-solving capacity if abused.
- Microsoft unveils the Muse AI model for Xbox, aiding game development and preservation of classic games.
- Muse generates game environments based on player actions, understanding 3D physics.
- The model trained on data from the game *Bleeding Edge*, utilizing seven years of gameplay data.
- Currently, Muse generates visuals at 300x180 pixels, a step up from previous models but still lower than standard gaming resolutions.
- Microsoft aims to enhance creativity in game development without replacing creators.

sources.title: Is AI making us dumb?
Microsoft’s Xbox AI era starts with a model that can generate gameplay

title: Pay to get playlisted? The accusations against Spotify’s Discovery Mode
summary:
- Spotify's Discovery Mode allows artists to accept lower royalty rates in exchange for algorithmic promotion, akin to payola practices.  
- Participating artists face a 30% reduction in royalties for tracks enrolled in the program, with only tracks over 30 days old eligible.  
- Discovery Mode has generated significant profits for Spotify, bringing in €61.4m in gross profits between May 2022 and May 2023, primarily from independent artists.  
- Critics argue that it creates inequities favoring larger labels, raises ethical concerns about undisclosed promotions, and could lead to a 'race to the bottom' for artist royalties.  
- The US government has warned that such practices could further undermine artists' incomes, especially post-pandemic.

sources.title: Pay to get playlisted? The accusations against Spotify’s Discovery Mode

title: Airbnb is suing New Orleans over regulatory ‘regime’
summary:
- Airbnb is suing New Orleans for requiring compliance with city laws for short-term rentals.
- City Council President J.P. Morrell stated the lawsuit implies Airbnb does not want regulation.
- New Orleans has faced challenges managing illegal short-term rentals while addressing affordable housing needs.
- In 2023, new regulations were adopted but enforcement has been difficult, with many illegal listings persisting.
- The lawsuit claims the city’s regulations represent a punitive enforcement regime and burdensome requirements for Airbnb.
- There are about 1,350 legal short-term rental properties versus over 7,000 active Airbnb listings in the city.
- The city has a significant affordable housing crisis, with a deficit of 47,000 units for lower-income residents.

title: The women who made America’s microchips and the children who paid for it
summary:
- The US aims to revive domestic chip manufacturing with ongoing concerns about health risks associated with past practices.
- Early semiconductor factory workers, mainly women, faced hazardous conditions leading to miscarriages and children with birth defects.
- Examples include Yvette and her son Mark, whose intellectual disabilities are attributed to exposure to harmful chemicals during production.
- Historical studies document higher miscarriage rates among semiconductor workers, prompting industry changes but lacking transparency.
- Recent reinvestment in US chipmaking raises fears about repeating past mistakes, with advocacy groups pushing for improved worker safety.

title: Go Module Mirror served backdoor to devs for 3+ years
summary:
- A backdoored package was served via the Go Module Mirror by Google for over three years.
- The malicious version was named boltdb-go/bolt, targeting users of the legitimate boltdb/bolt module.
- The issue arose from typosquatting, where users could inadvertently download the backdoored package due to minor name variations.
- Researchers petitioned for its removal after spotting the malicious code, which was cached despite a revert to the legitimate version on GitHub.

title: Palo Alto Networks warns of another firewall vulnerability under attack by hackers
summary:
- Palo Alto Networks confirmed hackers are exploiting a vulnerability in PAN-OS to breach unpatched customer networks.
- The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-0108, was discovered by Assetnote and is currently under active attack.
- Attackers are combining this vulnerability with previously disclosed flaws CVE-2024-9474 and CVE-2025-0111 to target unsecured web management interfaces.
- GreyNoise has reported 25 IP addresses actively exploiting the vulnerability, indicating an uptick in activity since only 2 addresses were noted earlier in February.
- The flaw allows unauthenticated attackers to execute PHP scripts, potentially leading to unauthorized access to systems.
- The highest levels of attack traffic have been observed in the U.S., Germany, and the Netherlands.
- The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added the vulnerability to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog.

sources.title: Palo Alto Networks warns of another firewall vulnerability under attack by hackers

title: AI-generated images can be art. They just can’t be photos
summary:
- Generative AI tools like DALL-E and Midjourney enable rapid creation of photo-like images. - Artist Matias Sauter Morera sold an AI-generated image to the Getty Museum for their upcoming exhibit.
- Sauter Morera emphasized that his AI images are not traditional photographs, as they don’t capture actual moments in time. - The article discusses the distinction between digital images created by AI and authentic photographs, raising concerns about misinformation. - The potential for AI-generated images to blend into realistic photography threatens the definition and understanding of photographic evidence.

sources.title: AI-generated images can be art. They just can’t be photos

title: A former Etsy product manager built an AI-powered app for new parents
summary:

- Riley is currently in public beta with a subscription model: $14.99/month, $11.99/month for a quarter, or $9.99/month for a year.

title: EU accused of leaving ‘devastating’ copyright loophole in AI Act
summary:
- EU's Artificial Intelligence Act has a copyright loophole that negatively impacts writers, musicians, and creatives.
- 15 cultural organizations warned the European Commission that draft rules on copyright are regressive.
- Axel Voss, a key figure in EU copyright law, stated that generative AI models weren't considered in earlier regulations leading to a legal gap.
- The AI Act requires compliance with 2019 copyright law but includes a text and data mining exemption criticized for benefiting large tech companies.
- Creatives are concerned about the lack of enforceable rights regarding the usage of their works in generative AI systems.
- No practical way for creatives to opt-out of their content being used in AI, and companies aren't obliged to disclose what content is utilized.
- Cultural organizations argue that the current EU law framework inadequately protects creative rights and insists on fair compensation for use of their works.

sources.title: EU accused of leaving ‘devastating’ copyright loophole in AI Act

summary:

- Supports up to 50 palm prints stored locally; can also be unlocked via keycode, app, or physical key.
- Contains a 15,000mAh removable rechargeable battery, with 6-12 months battery life.

- Launching on March 17; pre-orders available for existing customers at a $70 discount.

title: This AI tool could help curb domestic violence
summary:
- The Automated Intimate Partner Violence Risk Support System (AIRS) helps identify patients at risk for intimate partner violence (IPV) using clinical history and radiologic data.
- AIRS has been implemented in Brigham and Women's Hospital's Emergency Rooms and is being evaluated for clinical workflow integration.
- The tool was validated at the University of California-San Francisco Medical Center and relies on Electronic Health Records data.
- Key findings include indicators such as specific bone injuries linked to IPV, revealing the need for systematic detection.
- Challenges in data labeling and physician training highlight gaps in IPV diagnosis, with only 25% diagnosed correctly as noted in a May 2024 study published in Nature.

title: South Korea Blocks DeepSeek App Over Data Sharing Concerns with ByteDance
summary:
- South Korea has temporarily restricted downloads of DeepSeek's app pending an assessment of user data handling.
- The Personal Information Protection Commission (PIPC) indicated compliance with local privacy laws is required for the app's availability.
- Users are advised against entering personal data until a final decision is made regarding the app.
- Concerns arose after evidence surfaced that DeepSeek shared South Korean user data with ByteDance, TikTok's parent company.
- Access to DeepSeek has been blocked on official devices by South Korea's Ministry, police, and a state-run company due to security issues.
- Other countries, including Australia and Italy, have also restricted DeepSeek amid privacy and security concerns.
- The PIPC cited evidence of communication between DeepSeek and ByteDance but did not disclose specific data shared.
- Currently, DeepSeek is removed from Apple and Google’s app stores in South Korea but remains accessible via web browsers.
- The PIPC criticized DeepSeek for lack of transparency and warned users against entering personal information.
- A cybersecurity firm raised allegations about data potentially being transmitted to ByteDance servers linked to Chinese state entities.
- DeepSeek is cooperating with the ongoing investigation.

title: Apple Removes EU Apps Missing Trader Info Under Digital Law
summary:
- Apple has removed EU apps without required contact information to comply with the [Digital Services Act (DSA)](https://techcrunch.com/2025/02/18/apple-purges-apps-without-contact-info-from-eu-app-store-as-dsa-deadline-hits/).
- The deadline for providing developer contact details was February 17, 2025, and non-compliance led to app removals as of February 18, 2025.
- Smaller and indie developers, who often do not publicize contact info, face significant challenges meeting the new guidelines.
- Apple revised App Store policies on Feb. 18 to comply with DSA.
- DSA requires app developers to disclose trader details, affecting revenue-generating apps.
- 135,000 apps became inactive within 30 hours due to noncompliance, impacting small developers.
- Trader information is now displayed below app details in the EU App Store.
- Removed apps must provide verified trader details for reinstatement, heavily affecting independent developers.

- Microsoft’s carbon emissions rose by nearly 30% in 2023, while Amazon's progress towards emissions reduction has stalled despite investments in renewable energy.
- Microsoft purchased over 7 million metric tons of carbon credits last month, as companies strive to meet net-zero targets.

summary:
- Patrizia and Mitsui & Co. to invest up to $250 million in Philippine urban mobility company Parkwise.
- Investment comes from the APAC Sustainable Infrastructure Fund (A-SIF) to develop sustainable parking facilities.
- Parkwise plans to enhance infrastructure with EV charging stations and solar systems at key locations like hospitals and airports.
- This is A-SIF's second major investment in the Philippines after a 2024 solar energy project.
- Parkwise aims to address traffic congestion and parking shortages in major cities, particularly Manila.

sources.title: Philippines-based urban mobility firm boosted by $250m deal

title: Robinhood expands crypto services in Singapore
summary:
- Robinhood Markets Inc. plans to introduce cryptocurrency offerings in Singapore by late 2025.
- The initiative will be implemented through Bitstamp Ltd., acquired for US$200 million in June 2024.
- Johann Kerbrat, Robinhood Crypto VP, stated launch will occur after receiving regulatory guidance.
- Bitstamp has received in-principle approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore for its operations.

sources.title: Robinhood expands crypto services in Singapore

title: AI Security Platform and Startups Receive Significant Funding
summary:
- Candid Health raised $52.5 million in Series C funding, led by [Oak HC/FT](https://techcrunch.com/2025/02/12/six-months-after-raising-29m-candid-health-nabs-another-52-5m-to-ease-medical-billing/) and existing investors.
- Following a $29 million Series B round raised six months earlier, the startup aims to automate medical billing.
- Candid Health's revenue grew nearly 250% in 2024, highlighting its rapid growth.
- The company utilizes a rules engine for accurate claims submissions and plans to incorporate AI features.

- Abu Dhabi-based G42 leads a $55 million Series A funding for [AppliedAI](https://www.techinasia.com/news/ai-automation-firm-secures-55m-from-microsoft-backed-g42), focusing on healthcare and other industries.
- Contributors include [Bessemer Venture Partners](https://www.techinasia.com/news/us-based-ai-security-platform-raises-10m-seed-funding), Palantir, and McKinsey.
- G42 supports two upcoming AI centers in Abu Dhabi.

- [Singulr AI](https://www.techinasia.com/news/us-based-ai-security-platform-raises-10m-seed-funding) raised $10 million in seed funding, spearheaded by Nexus Venture Partners and Dell Technologies Capital.
- The platform deals with AI governance and security, managing over 500 AI services and enabling continuous discovery and automated risk scoring.
- Funding will enhance tools addressing the rise in enterprise AI demand.

sources.title: Six months after raising $29M, Candid Health nabs another $52.5M to ease medical billing
AI automation firm secures $55m from Microsoft-backed G42
US-based AI security platform raises $10m seed funding

title: Truth review – Julian Assange play is hard going, with flashes of brilliance
summary:
- The play 'Truth' is directed by Susie Dee and written by Patricia Cornelius, focusing on Julian Assange and geopolitical issues.
- It features five actors representing different facets of Assange, but the portrayal lacks nuance, emphasizing grievance instead.
- Key themes include Assange's hacking background, the WikiLeaks controversy, and comparisons with figures like Chelsea Manning and Edward Snowden.
- Cornelius presents a one-dimensional view of Assange as a leftist figure without acknowledging conflicting narratives.
- Certain scenes unrelated to Assange resonate thematically, highlighting emotional stakes.
- Although some production elements are compelling, the overall narrative is described as a slog lacking depth.

sources.title: Truth review – Julian Assange play is hard going, with flashes of brilliance

title: Why CX is every brand’s biggest opportunity
summary:
- Customer experience (CX) is crucial as companies face struggles with AI and digital transformation.
- Companies that integrate technologies and focus on customer experience can gain a competitive advantage.
- Trend 1: Bridge the AI perception gap; consumer sentiment toward AI is improving, presenting an opportunity for brands.
- Trend 2: Shift from systems of record to systems of action, enabling businesses to respond in real-time to customer interactions.
- Trend 3: Demand for hyperpersonalized experiences is rising; brands must connect digital and human interactions.
- Trend 4: CX has evolved into a strategic growth driver for businesses, requiring a shift in metrics and cross-functional alignment.
- Trend 5: Choose AI partnerships wisely, focusing on proven results and enhancing human-machine collaboration.

sources.title: Why CX is every brand’s biggest opportunity

title: Reddit vs. Wall Street: the latest in the GameStop saga
summary:
- GameStop announces plans to sell its operations in Canada and France due to factors cited as "wokeness and DEI" by CEO Ryan Cohen.
- E*Trade considers shutting down the account of Keith Gill, a prominent figure in the WallStreetBets community, amidst speculations of market manipulation.
- Gill's previous involvement in the GameStop frenzy of 2021 led to an uptick in stock prices again, raising concerns from the SEC regarding potential manipulation.

sources.title: Reddit vs. Wall Street: the latest in the GameStop saga

title: Elon Musk Faces Conflict of Interest Amid Neuralink Advances and FDA Layoffs
summary:
- Noland Arbaugh, paralyzed since June 2016, became the first human recipient of a Neuralink brain-computer interface in January 2024.
- He can control a computer and play games using the N1 chip implanted in his brain.
- Elon Musk is criticized for conflicts of interest tied to his businesses as 20 FDA employees overseeing Neuralink were recently laid off.
- Layoffs may slow Neuralink's progress in implanting devices.
- Reduced FDA oversight raises concerns about patient safety.
- Neuralink plans to implant devices in more patients despite staff challenges.

sources.title: Elon Musk put a chip in this paralysed man’s brain. Now he can move things with his mind. Should we be amazed - or terrified?

title: AI Hallucinations Could Get Lawyers Fired, Law Firm Says
summary:
- Morgan & Morgan warns over 1,000 lawyers about the dangers of AI-generated case law.  
- A federal judge threatened sanctions against lawyers for including fake case citations in a lawsuit against Walmart.  
- AI's tendency to create fictional information has led to disciplinary actions in several cases across the U.S.  
- 63% of lawyers have used AI in their work, though caution is advised due to the risk of 'hallucinations'.

sources.title: AI Hallucinations Could Get Lawyers Fired, Law Firm Says

title: FTC Chair praises Justice Thomas as ‘the most important judge of the last 100 years’ for Black History Month
summary:
- FTC Chair Andrew Ferguson praised Justice Clarence Thomas in a memo for Black History Month, calling him the most important judge of the last 100 years.
- Ferguson emphasized Thomas's success despite a difficult upbringing, stating he embodies the American spirit of overcoming adversity.
- The memo indicated Ferguson may align his policies with Thomas, especially regarding consumer protection cases involving potential racial bias in technology.
- Ferguson has already distanced himself from prior FTC chair Lina Khan’s approach, declaring a halt to diversity initiatives at the agency.

sources.title: FTC Chair praises Justice Thomas as ‘the most important judge of the last 100 years’ for Black History Month

title: Humane’s AI Pin Acquisition and Meta's Move for AI Chip Startup FuriosaAI
summary:
- Meta is negotiating to acquire [FuriosaAI](https://techcrunch.com/2025/02/12/report-meta-in-talks-to-acquire-ai-chip-firm-furiosaai/), a South Korean AI chip startup founded by ex-Samsung and AMD engineers.
- The acquisition aims to enhance Meta's AI hardware capabilities for models like Llama 2 and Llama 3.
- FuriosaAI has raised approximately $61.94 million and is engaging with customers in the U.S., Japan, and India.
- This strategy aims to reduce Meta’s dependence on Nvidia while investing up to $65 billion in AI by 2025.
- FuriosaAI has developed AI inference accelerators and launched the RNGD chip, which is priced around $10,000 compared to Nvidia’s $40,000 H100.
- The potential acquisition is expected to be concluded by the end of February 2025.
- Following the news, shares of FuriosaAI’s investors rose on Korea’s Kosdaq market.

- [Humane](https://techcrunch.com/2025/02/18/humanes-ai-pin-is-dead-as-hp-buys-startups-assets-for-116m/) announces acquisition of its assets by HP for $116 million.
- Discontinuation of AI Pin sales; devices will stop functioning on February 28, 2025.
- AI Pin users advised to transfer data; customer support for AI Pin will dissolve on same date.
- HP includes Humane's engineers and technology, including CosmOS AI operating system, to form an AI innovation lab.
- Humane previously aimed for a higher acquisition price of $750 million to $1 billion in 2024.

sources.title: Meta in Talks to Acquire AI Chip Firm FuriosaAI
Meta in talks to acquire South Korean AI chip startup
Humane’s AI Pin is dead, as HP buys startup’s assets for $116M

title: Humane's AI Pin Discontinued Following HP Acquisition for $116 Million
summary:
- Humane is selling its AI capabilities to HP for $116 million and discontinuing the AI Pin.
- AI Pins will function until 3PM ET on February 28, 2025, after which they will lose connectivity to Humane’s servers and many features.
- Refunds for AI Pins are available within 90 days from shipment, and prorated refunds for subscriptions past the shutdown date will be processed.
- HP will acquire Humane’s platform Cosmos, technical talent, and extensive intellectual property.
- The AI Pin faced poor sales and negative reviews, leading Humane to seek acquisition shortly after its launch.
- Customers have been notified that their AI Pins will stop working on February 28, 2025, at 12 PM PST, ceasing connectivity and functionality.
- Humane will dissolve its customer support team for the AI Pin on the same date and has advised users to back up their data.

sources.title: Humane is shutting down the AI Pin and selling its remnants to HP
Humane’s AI Pin is dead, as HP buys startup for $116M

title: Humane’s AI Pin: All the Latest News on the Failing Wearable
summary:
- Humane is recalling the AI Pin’s charging case due to overheating concerns.
- Daily returns of the AI Pin are outpacing sales since its launch.
- A review claims the AI Pin does not meet expectations.
- Users should backup data before February 28, 2025, when AI Pin features will cease functioning.
- Humane is selling its AI technology to HP for $116 million and will no longer sell the AI Pin.
- The AI Pin was priced at $699 and faced criticism for its performance and usability.
- Customers are encouraged to stop using the charging case due to fire risks associated with the battery.

title: DOGE can keep accessing government data for now, judge rules
summary:
- A US federal judge allowed Elon Musk's DOGE to access data from seven government agencies.
- The judge denied a temporary restraining order sought by 14 Democratic state attorneys general, citing insufficient evidence of irreparable harm.
- The case raises questions about Musk's appointment under the Appointments Clause, indicating potential executive abuses.
- The states may still pursue the case on its merits and seek a preliminary injunction against DOGE's data access.

sources.title: DOGE can keep accessing government data for now, judge rules

title: OpenAI cofounder Ilya Sutskever’s new AI startup is fundraising with a $30 billion valuation
summary:
- Ilya Sutskever’s startup, Safe Superintelligence (SSI), is raising over $1 billion at a $30 billion valuation.
- Greenoaks Capital Partners leads the investment, planning to contribute $500 million.
- SSI reported a previous valuation of $5 billion in September 2023, when it raised $1 billion from investors.
- SSI aims to build a "safe superintelligent AI system" but has no product yet.
- Sutskever co-founded SSI after departing OpenAI, where he played a significant role.
- His recent actions include a controversy involving the temporary removal of Sam Altman from OpenAI's CEO position.

title: Mira Murati Launches Thinking Machines Lab After OpenAI
summary:
- Mira Murati, ex-CTO of OpenAI, is launching a new AI startup called [Thinking Machines Lab](https://thinkingmachines.ai/).
- The startup aims to make AI systems more understandable, customizable, and capable, with a commitment to public transparency through regular publication of technical research and code.
- Murati has recruited notable figures from OpenAI, including co-founder John Schulman and CTO Barrett Zoph, building a team of about 10 top researchers from elite AI labs.
- The startup focuses on AI alignment, aiming to encode human values into AI models for safety and reliability.
- This initiative reflects a trend of former OpenAI executives starting new companies in the AI sector.

sources.title: Mira Murati is launching her OpenAI rival: Thinking Machines Lab
After leaving OpenAI, Mira Murati debuts her AI startup, Thinking Machines Lab

title: Microsoft warns that the powerful XCSSET macOS malware is back with new tricks
summary:
- Microsoft reports that XCSSET macOS malware has been upgraded with enhanced features.
- New capabilities include targeting digital wallets, collecting data from the Notes app, and exfiltrating system information.
- Microsoft Defender for Endpoint on Mac now detects this new variant, with future indicators of compromise to be provided.
- Developers are advised to inspect all Xcode projects downloaded from repositories to avoid malware infections.

title: Cutting-edge Chinese “reasoning” model rivals OpenAI o1—and it’s free to download + DeepSeek challenges OpenAI with R1 model
summary:
- DeepSeek, a Chinese AI lab, unveiled its R1 model, developed for under US$6 million, outpacing US rivals like OpenAI in cost.
- The R1 model reportedly matches OpenAI's O1 in performance while being more energy-efficient.
- Concerns about censorship arise as the model avoids politically sensitive topics.
- OpenAI questions DeepSeek's cost claims, suggesting expenses exceed US$500 million and the possibility of model "distillation."
- Chinese reasoning model R1 reportedly outperforms OpenAI's o1 on several benchmarks.
- DeepSeek, Alibaba, and Moonshot AI claim their models match o1's capabilities.
- R1 has restrictions on certain topics due to Chinese Internet regulations when run in the cloud.

title: Trump admin reverses hydropower layoffs that sparked grid stability fears
summary:
- The Trump administration instituted cuts to federal agencies managing hydropower, laying off 13% to 20% of employees, raising concerns about grid stability.
- Criticism from lawmakers led to the rehiring of some laid-off staff.
- Power Marketing Administrations manage the sale and transmission of hydropower from federal dams, supporting electricity for tens of millions across 34 states.

sources.title: Trump admin reverses hydropower layoffs that sparked grid stability fears

title: Facebook is about to mass delete a lot of old live streams
summary:
- Facebook will delete live broadcast recordings after **30 days** starting on **February 19th**.  
- Users must download videos within 30 days to prevent deletion; clips can also be shared as **Reels** with a 90-second limit.  
- Notifications will be sent before deletion, allowing **90 days** to save videos; deletion will happen in waves.  
- Facebook provides download tools for saving individual or bulk videos, with options to transfer to cloud services like **Dropbox** or **Google Drive**.  
- A postpone request feature allows users an additional **six months** to save their videos.

summary:
- Duolingo's mascot, Duo the owl, is humorously declared dead after being 'hit by a Cybertruck'.
- CEO Luis von Ahn read a eulogy for Duo on TikTok, causing a significant spike in user engagement.
- Duolingo saw a 25% increase in monthly active Android users and a 38% jump in downloads the day after the announcement.
- The 'Duo or die' campaign allows users to save the mascot by completing lessons and maintaining streaks.
- Duolingo's marketing tactics are seen as aggressive yet clever, paralleling trends in startup engagement strategies.

title: Google Meet's AI transcripts will automatically create action items for you
summary:
- Google Meet introduces a Gemini-powered note-taking feature for Workspace teams that generates action items post-meeting.
- The feature rolls out on **February 18, 2025**, suggesting next steps with due dates and assigned stakeholders.
- Gemini's transcription separates speakers and summarizes discussions, sharing the output in a structured Google Doc with participants.

title: GTA VI: Key Updates on Release and User-Generated Content
summary:
- Rockstar announced the first trailer for GTA VI will be revealed on December 5, 2023, but leaked early.
- The game will return to Vice City, featuring a new protagonist named Lucia.
- In 2022, hacker Arion Kurtaj leaked 90 videos related to the game, leading to his conviction in 2023.
- There are unconfirmed reports of recent leaks showing gameplay footage and maps allegedly from a Rockstar employee's child.
- Reports suggest Rockstar is focusing on user-generated content by collaborating with creators from games like Fortnite and Roblox.
- GTA VI is set to launch in Fall 2025, with GTA V having sold over 210 million copies.
- The reveal trailer of GTA VI has garnered record-breaking views, surpassing earlier GTA V's trailer views in a matter of hours.
- Rockstar previously banned FiveM creators in 2015 but later acquired the team in 2023 as user-generated content gained popularity.
- This strategy aims to ensure GTA VI's success in a competitive gaming marketplace by leveraging the popularity of platforms that support creator content.

Rockstar’s working on bringing Roblox creators to GTA VI

title: Amazon Discontinues TikTok-Style Inspire Feature
summary:
- Amazon is shutting down its TikTok-like feature ‘Inspire’ designed for discovering products.
- This decision follows customer feedback indicating ‘Inspire’ is no longer needed.
- The shutdown occurs amidst TikTok's uncertain status in the U.S., which could have legitimized ‘Inspire’ as a product discovery tool.
- Amazon has sought partnerships with Instagram and Snap to improve shopping experiences externally.
- Launched in 2022, ‘Inspire’ struggled with creator engagement and compensation, facing criticism for low payment rates.
- Users are still encouraged to seek product inspiration through other avenues and upcoming AI features.

sources.title: Amazon kills ‘Inspire,’ its TikTok-style feed for discovering products
Amazon scraps its TikTok-style Inspire feed

summary:
- Safe Superintelligence, founded by Ilya Sutskever, seeks to raise funding at a valuation of at least $20 billion as of February 7, 2025.
- New valuation is four times its previous $5 billion valuation from September 2024.
- The startup has raised $1 billion to date and is backed by investors like Sequoia Capital and Andreessen Horowitz.
- It is notable that Safe Superintelligence has yet to generate revenue.
- The startup is close to raising additional funds in a round led by Greenoaks Capital Partners with a pledge of half a billion dollars.

summary:
- Leaked images reveal Sony's new transparent color option for their ANC earbuds, the WF-C710N, set to launch in late May with features like [Sony’s Quick Attention Mode](https://helpguide.sony.net/mdr/2963/v1/en/contents/TP1000781422.html).
- The WF-C710N will be available in four colors, including a new glass blue with a fully transparent design for the buds and charging case.
- Retro Remake has opened preorders for the SuperStation One ($149.99 Founders Edition sold out; standard price $225, currently $179.99), designed like the PS One but with FPGA capabilities for multiple console emulations.
- Xbox announced the Pulse Cipher Special Edition controller, featuring a deep-red transparent casing, priced at $74.99 and available on February 4th.
- Asus introduced a NUC AI mini PC with a color E Ink display, further expanding transparent tech possibilities.

title: Electricity Demand Surges: Growth Projections for Major Polluters
summary:
- Global electricity demand projected to increase by **4% annually** through **2027** according to the **International Energy Agency**.
- Meeting this demand will require new generating capacity exceeding Japan's total capacity each year.
- **85%** of growth will come from emerging and developing economies, with China driving a **6% annual growth rate**.
- U.S. electricity demand growth will be significant but lower than China's, equivalent to California's current demand.
- Low-carbon sources, including renewables and nuclear, expected to fulfill nearly all demand growth.
- Significant increase in electricity demand from China and the U.S. driven by data centers and electric vehicle manufacturing.
- Global demand growth expected to equal Japan’s annual consumption added each year until 2027.
- China’s electricity usage has outpaced economic growth since **2020**, especially in the solar, EV, and battery sectors.
- U.S. demand anticipated to rise by **2% annually** through **2027**, primarily due to data center needs.
- IEA highlights the necessity for cleaner energy sources to satisfy rising electricity demands without increasing pollution, with renewables predicted to comprise a significant portion of new generation.

sources.title: Global electricity demand expected to grow 4% annually through 2027
Electricity demand surges for the world’s two biggest polluters

title: Acer Raises Laptop Prices Due to Trump Tariffs Affecting Big Tech
summary:
- President Trump imposed a 25% tariff on steel and aluminum impacting multiple industries.
- Tariffs specifically affect imports from Canada, Mexico, and China, yet Big Tech remains mostly silent.
- De minimis exemption for goods under $800 suspended, complicating shipments from China.
- Shipping companies may experience delays and increased charges due to tariffs.
- Smaller firms like Qwertykeys have stopped shipments to the US because of tariff costs.
- Acer CEO announced a 10% price increase on laptops in the US starting next month, attributed to the import tax on Chinese goods.
- The price increase affects laptops, not desktops, as they are manufactured outside China.
- Other companies might raise prices more than 10% due to tariffs.

sources.title: US tariffs: how Trump’s tax is hitting Big Tech and beyond
Acer is the first to raise laptop prices because of Trump

- Murati is in talks to raise over $100 million for [Thinking Machines Lab](https://thinkingmachines.ai/).
- The startup focuses on customizable AI systems to improve understanding and capabilities.
- Murati is the CEO, Schulman is chief scientist, and Barret Zoph is CTO.
- Emphasis on AI safety and preventing misuse of AI technologies.

Thinking Machines Lab is ex-OpenAI CTO Mira Murati’s new startup

title: Three months later, S.T.A.L.K.E.R. 2 is the glorious pain in the ass its makers intended
summary:
- Release of *S.T.A.L.K.E.R. 2: Heart of Chornobyl* initially criticized for lacking life and activity in the game world.
- After three months, two major and five smaller patches have significantly improved enemy AI and reduced bugs.
- Enhanced AI leads to more dynamic combat situations and immersive experiences, bringing the game's environment to life.
- Latest patch includes 1,700 improvements, including level design tweaks and better NPC behavior, such as looting.
- Developers express commitment to improving the game post-launch, highlighting its essence and emotional resonance with players.

title: VC giant Insight Partners confirms January cyberattack
summary:
- Insight Partners confirmed a cyberattack occurred in January.
- The attack, a sophisticated social engineering incident, was detected on January 16.
- The firm has over $90 billion in assets and has notified its stakeholders about the breach.
- The nature of the incident remains undisclosed, including whether any data was stolen.
- Insight Partners reassured partners to enhance security protocols.

sources.title: VC giant Insight Partners confirms January cyberattack

title: WhatsApp is now a Very Large platform in the EU, and will face tougher regulation
summary:
- WhatsApp has exceeded 45 million users, qualifying it as a Very Large Online Platform (VLOP) under the EU’s Digital Services Act (DSA).
- The designation subjects WhatsApp to stricter regulations including user reporting tools for illegal content and restrictions on targeted advertising.
- WhatsApp's monthly active users were approximately 46.8 million as of February 14, 2024, according to a recent filing.
- Facebook and Instagram are already classified as VLOPs in the EU, facing similar regulations.

sources.title: WhatsApp is now a Very Large platform in the EU, and will face tougher regulation

title: Fiverr wants gig workers to offload some of their work to AI
summary:
- Fiverr introduces a program allowing freelancers to train AI on their work and automate tasks.
- This initiative is aimed at voiceover and graphic design freelancers, allowing them to charge customers for AI-generated work.
- Fiverr CEO Micha Kaufman emphasizes supporting gig workers with credit and compensation while scaling their work.
- The gig market is challenged by generative AI, with many roles facing reduced demand.
- The “Personal AI Creation Model” enables freelancers to configure AI based on their prior projects and set usage fees.
- Freelancers remain owners of the generated work produced by their AI model.
- Fiverr is prioritizing the privacy of freelancers by not using their data to create competing models.
- A “Personal AI Assistant” will be available for monthly fees, helping freelancers manage client interactions effectively.
- Fiverr plans to reward top-performing contractors with shares in the company.

sources.title: Fiverr wants gig workers to offload some of their work to AI

title: Magic: The Gathering’s Final Fantasy sets will tell the stories of the games
summary:
- Magic: The Gathering revealed its upcoming Final Fantasy-themed set.
- The initial look includes character cards from Final Fantasy games with associated pre-constructed Commander decks.
- Cards featured include Terra, Tidus, Y’shtola, and Cloud, each deck narrating a specific Final Fantasy game's story.
- The full set will represent all 16 mainline Final Fantasy games and launches on June 13th, 2024.
- Art by famous Final Fantasy artist Yoshitaka Amano will feature in the set.

sources.title: Magic: The Gathering’s Final Fantasy sets will tell the stories of the games

title: Facebook now only stores live videos for 30 days, will delete old broadcasts
summary:
- Facebook announced that live videos will now only be stored for 30 days; previously, they were stored indefinitely.
- Effective immediately, all live videos older than 30 days will be deleted, with users notified and given 90 days to download or transfer their content.
- Users can store videos in cloud services or convert them into reels; Facebook is promoting these reels as part of the new policy.
- If more time is needed for downloads, users can defer deletion by six months; failure to act will result in permanent deletion.
- Facebook is launching new download tools to assist users in managing their live video content.

sources.title: Facebook now only stores live videos for 30 days, will delete old broadcasts

title: Steam Game PirateFi Removed Due to Malware Threats
summary:
- Valve removed the game *PirateFi* from Steam due to malware presence.
- Users are advised to fully reformat their operating systems.
- The game had a 9/10 rating from 51 reviews before removal.
- Valve urges users to run a full-system scan and check for unexpected software.
- The type of malware has not been specified by Valve.
- Security researchers discovered the malware, an info-stealer named Vidar, was distributed via modified games.
- Vidar can steal various types of sensitive data, including passwords and cryptocurrency wallet information.
- Researchers suspect that PirateFI was a tactic to spread Vidar and was not a legitimate game.
- Infostealers like Vidar are often sold as malware-as-a-service, complicating attribution.
- The game was reportedly built using an existing game template, making it easy to deploy malicious software.

sources.title: Valve removes Steam game that contained malware
Hackers planted a Steam game with malware to steal gamers’ passwords

title: OpenAI may give board special voting rights to ward off takeover attempts
summary:
- OpenAI is considering granting special voting rights to its non-profit board to prevent hostile takeover attempts.
- This would enable the board to overrule major investors and maintain some authority as the company transitions to a for-profit structure.
- Recently, Elon Musk's group offered $97.4 billion to buy OpenAI’s nonprofit, which was unanimously rejected by the board.
- OpenAI plans to separate its nonprofit and for-profit arms by late 2026.

sources.title: OpenAI may give board special voting rights to ward off takeover attempts

title: Elon Musk Launches Grok-3 Chatbot While DeepSeek Surges in AI Market
summary:
- DeepSeek's chatbot recently topped charts on Apple App Store and Google Play.
- Backed by High-Flyer Capital Management, it focuses on AI-driven trading.
- Established in 2023, DeepSeek emphasizes strong university recruitment.
- Competitive models like DeepSeek-V2 and V3 prioritize efficiency.
- DeepSeek’s R1 model matches OpenAI on key benchmarks.
- Regulatory challenges in China affect DeepSeek’s operations and accessibility.
- DeepSeek models are integrated into Microsoft Azure AI Foundry despite data privacy concerns.

- Elon Musk’s xAI releases Grok-3, integrated with X (formerly Twitter).
- Grok-3 competes with AI firms including DeepSeek, OpenAI, and Google.
- Available to Premium+ subscribers; SuperGrok subscription tier introduced for mobile users.
- Grok-3 can generate texts and images, but lacks explicit content filters.
- Musk claims Grok-3 has over 10 times the power of Grok-2, introducing a search engine called DeepSearch.
- Investors are raising billions to boost xAI’s data capacity; Musk's Colossus supercomputer is the largest globally.
- A $97.4 billion bid to acquire OpenAI's assets was turned down.

title: Federal Employees Laid Off by Elon Musk’s DOGE Share Anxieties on Reddit
summary:
- Federal employees across more than two dozen government departments were abruptly fired on Valentine's Day, linked to Elon Musk's Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE).

title: 22-year-old math wiz indicted for alleged DeFI hack that stole $65M
summary:
- A man named Andean Medjedovic was indicted for allegedly stealing $65 million in cryptocurrency through two DeFI hacks.
- The incidents occurred in 2021 and 2023, involving KyberSwap and Indexed Finance platforms.
- Medjedovic exploited smart contract vulnerabilities and used manipulative trading practices to maximize his theft, stealing approximately $48.8 million from 77 liquidity pools.
- He attempted to extort developers and return part of the stolen funds in exchange for control of the KyberSwap protocol.
- Efforts to launder the proceeds included using cryptocurrency mixers and bridge protocols, but a mishap led to his arrest.

title: Cyberattacks Impacting Ascension Healthcare and Lee Enterprises' Newspaper Operations
summary:

- A filing in December confirmed the scale of the breach and types of data compromised.
- Lee Enterprises reports ongoing cyberattack causing disruptions for over three weeks.
- Forensic analysis ongoing to determine if sensitive data was compromised in the ransomware attack.
- Anticipated further outages affecting operations including distribution, billing, and payments.
- Several newspapers, including Winston-Salem Journal and two Oregon-based papers, have experienced printing delays.
- Lee Enterprises is one of the largest newspaper publishers in the U.S., servicing 72 publications.
- Material impact on the company's financial results is considered likely.

title: OpenAI Board Rejects Elon Musk's $97.4 Billion Acquisition Bid
summary:
- OpenAI’s board rejected Elon Musk’s $97.4 billion acquisition bid, stating that "OpenAI is not for sale."

- CEO Sam Altman criticized the bid as a hindrance to progress, and legal counsel asserted that competitors cannot dictate OpenAI’s mission.

- This study aims to create accessible reasoning benchmarks that don’t require advanced knowledge, promoting better understanding of AI capabilities.

title: 161 years ago, a New Zealand sheep farmer predicted AI doom
summary:
- A New Zealand sheep farmer, Samuel Butler, predicted AI safety concerns such as machine consciousness and self-replication over 161 years ago.
- His writings influenced themes in later works like Asimov's and Frank Herbert's novels.
- Butler's 1872 novel, Erewhon, illustrated a society that banned machines invented within the last 300 years due to concerns about machine evolution.
- He emphasized the relationship between the evolution of machines and Darwinian principles, expressing admiration for Darwin's work.
- Despite being written in a time of rudimentary calculating devices, Butler's predictions about machine intelligence have proven to be remarkably insightful and relevant today.

summary:

- New regulations build on previous chip controls from September 2022 and October 2023, set to take effect in 120 days.
- First-tier countries face no restrictions, while second-tier countries can receive a limited number of advanced computing chips based on agreements with the US.
- Orders of up to 1,700 advanced chips do not require licenses, facilitating purchases by educational and medical institutions.

title: Widely used DNA sequencer still doesn’t enforce Secure Boot
summary:
- In 2012, an industry coalition adopted Secure Boot to protect devices against malware.
- Secure Boot uses public-key cryptography to prevent unauthorized code from loading.
- Microsoft requires Secure Boot for Windows devices, but not for specialized devices like the Illumina iSeq 100 DNA sequencer.
- The iSeq 100 can boot from legacy BIOS and uses outdated firmware with critical vulnerabilities.
- Firmware Read/Write protections are not enabled, allowing potential firmware modifications by attackers.
- The vulnerabilities could affect a broad range of devices using similar OEM motherboards.

title: UK Government Orders Apple to Create iCloud Backdoor for Encrypted Data Access
summary:
- The UK government secretly ordered Apple to create a backdoor for accessing users' encrypted iCloud data.
- The demand was made in January under the UK's Investigatory Powers Act 2016, requesting blanket access to all encrypted files.
- Apple may stop offering its encrypted cloud storage, Advanced Data Protection, to UK users due to this demand.
- A technical capability notice under the Investigatory Powers Act requires Apple to assist law enforcement globally.
- Apple's Advanced Data Protection service utilizes end-to-end encryption, meaning only account holders can decrypt files.
- Apple has stated it would refuse to build a backdoor and withdraw security features from the UK market instead.
- The UK government’s demand may lead to conflicts with EU data-sharing agreements.
- This move is part of a broader effort to enhance national security and public safety.
- Concerns about privacy and data security among users and technology experts are being raised in response to the demand.
- Critics fear this sets a dangerous precedent, potentially weakening security for Apple users worldwide and eroding civil liberties.
- Security experts warn that backdoors could be exploited by malicious actors, leading to identity theft and data breaches.
- The concept of a 'NOBUS' backdoor suggests only authorized agents would have access, but this is heavily criticized as a flawed idea.

sources.title: UK government demands Apple backdoor to encrypted cloud data: report

UK demands Apple backdoor for encrypted cloud data

title: These Google Photos alternatives offer tons of storage options at a reasonable price
summary:

- Alternatives to Google Photos include:
  - **[Flickr](https://www.flickr.com/)**: 1,000 photos for free; paid plans start at $10.44/month for unlimited storage.
  - **[Dropbox](https://www.dropbox.com/)**: 5GB free; paid plans start at $9.99/month for 2TB.
  - **[Ente](https://ente.io/)**: 5GB free, focuses on privacy; paid plans start at $2.49/month for 50GB.
  - **[Cryptee](https://crypt.ee/)**: 100MB free; paid plans start at $3.30/month for 10GB, includes document editor features.
  - **[Amazon Photos](https://www.amazon.com/Amazon-Photos/b?ie=UTF8&node=13234696011)**: 5GB free with Prime membership; paid plans start at $1.99/month for 100GB.
  - **[500px](https://500px.com/)**: Allows 21 high-resolution photos per week for free; premium plans start under $50/year.
  - **[Photobucket](https://photobucket.com/)**: No free storage; $5/month for 1TB.

title: What is device code phishing, and why are Russian spies so successful at it?
summary:
- Researchers have uncovered a phishing campaign by Russian spies targeting Microsoft 365 accounts using a technique called device code phishing.
- Device code phishing exploits OAuth's device code flow, designed for devices that don't support browsers (e.g., printers, smart TVs).
- Adversaries have been using this method since at least last August, impersonating trusted officials to initiate conversations on messaging apps.

title: The EV Tax Credit and Recent Legislative Changes
summary:
- Two bills introduced in the Senate aim to significantly increase electric vehicle prices.
- The Eliminating Lavish Incentives to Electric (ELITE) Vehicles Act would eliminate the $7,500 EV tax credit and other incentives, sponsored by Sen. John Barrasso.
- The Fair Sharing of Highways and Roads for Electric Vehicles (Fair SHARE) Act would impose a $1,000 tax on EV purchases, introduced by Sen. Deb Fischer.
- Both bills face potential opposition from some Republicans whose districts benefit from Biden’s EV investments.
- The $1,000 fee is designed to match gas taxes an average gasoline car owner would pay over ten years.

- The EV tax credit offers up to $7,500 off new electric vehicle purchases.
- Eligibility is based on various criteria including manufacturing location, battery sourcing, vehicle price, and buyer's income.
- The credit aims to promote energy security and reduce reliance on Chinese battery manufacturers.
- Automakers are moving to establish North American manufacturing to comply with the credit's requirements.
- The list of eligible vehicles changes frequently as the industry adapts to the new rules.
- Recent Senate bills aim to eliminate the credit and impose new fees on EV purchases.
- Hyundai, Kia, and Genesis vehicles have become eligible for the tax credit, reflecting ongoing industry adjustments.

title: Amazon to Remove Download Feature for Kindle Books Starting February 2025
summary:
- Amazon will remove the 'Download & Transfer via USB' feature on February 26, 2025, affecting how Kindle users back up their books.
- This feature allows users to download purchased books to their computers for backup or conversion to other formats.
- Users without Wi-Fi may find this feature useful as it provides offline copies of their books, especially in light of Amazon's history of removing titles remotely.
- The feature supports the AZW3 format for older devices; modern Kindles use KFX format, which has strict DRM protection.
- After the change, users can still use apps to send documents to Kindles via USB but cannot directly download purchased books to a computer anymore.
- Amazon has not provided a specific reason for the removal of this feature.

title: Kagi’s search engine adds a more private way to search
summary:
- Kagi introduces a new privacy feature called [Privacy Pass](https://blog.kagi.com/kagi-privacy-pass) for its search engine.
- Privacy Pass allows users to make searches without them being traceable to their identities.
- This feature uses an authentication protocol that generates tokens which cannot be linked back to the user.
- Kagi emphasizes the technical impossibility of tracking users while allowing them to search freely.
- Users can enable Privacy Pass in Kagi's Orion browser (available on macOS, iOS, and iPadOS), the Kagi app for Android, and in browser extensions for Firefox and Chrome.
- Kagi also supports access via Tor with a specific onion address but warns that without Privacy Pass, searches can still be linked to user accounts.
- Privacy Pass is available for $10/month Professional plan and $25/month Ultimate plan users, not included in free or $5/month Starter plans.

title: Turo Cancels IPO Amid Revenue Slowdown and Market Challenges
summary:
- Turo has withdrawn its plans for an IPO after a three-year wait, according to a regulatory filing.
- The company publicly filed for an IPO in January 2022 but faced changing market conditions and decelerating growth.
- Turo's decision follows the recent shutdown of peer-to-peer car-sharing company Getaround's U.S. operations.
- As of September 2024, Turo reported 150,000 active hosts globally and $722 million in revenue for the first nine months of 2024, an 8.6% increase from 2023, but down from $879.7 million in 2022.
- The business saw a decline in 2023 but has shown signs of recovery in 2024, though not enough to pursue an IPO.
- Turo canceled its planned IPO, as per a regulatory filing on Feb. 13.
- The company had announced plans for an IPO in 2021 and filed in January 2022, but faced delays due to unfavorable market conditions.
- CEO Andre Haddad stated "now is not the right time" for the IPO; Turo will focus on long-term value.
- Revenue grew from US$150 million in 2020 to US$958 million in 2024, but momentum has slowed since the pandemic peak.
- Turo has been profitable since 2022, but net income fell from US$154.7 million in 2022 to US$14.7 million in 2023.
- Competitor Getaround announced the shutdown of its US operations, indicating ongoing challenges in the car-sharing industry.

- An “orderly wind-down” of US operations was approved on Feb. 7, with most layoffs scheduled by Feb. 14.
- Shutdown costs are estimated between US$1.5 million and US$2 million.

title: FBI’s warrantless ‘backdoor’ searches ruled unconstitutional
summary:

• In 2023, the FBI conducted over 57,000 searches of US person data, a 52% decrease from 2022.
• The ruling declares warrantless searches unreasonable and calls for a legislative warrant requirement to protect citizens’ rights.

title: Apple Investigated by German Watchdog for Potential Antitrust Violations
summary:
- Germany's antitrust watchdog, Bundeskartellamt (FCO), is investigating Apple's app privacy framework since 2022.
- FCO suspects Apple may not treat third-party app developers equally, potentially amounting to self-preferencing.
- New regulations under the Digital Markets Act prohibit self-preferencing by big tech on iOS and core platform services like the App Store.
- The investigation focuses on Apple's App Tracking Transparency framework, which treats third-party tracking permissions differently than its own.
- Concerns were raised about unequal treatment in consent dialogues and the strict application of tracking definitions against third-party apps.
- Apple is given the opportunity to respond to the FCO's findings prior to any formal advocacy or acting on it.
- The German antitrust authority has charged Apple with abusing its market power through its app tracking tool.
- This investigation follows three years of scrutiny regarding Apple’s App Tracking Transparency feature.
- The feature has faced criticism from Meta Platforms and app developers for making it difficult for competitors to access user data relevant for advertising.
- Apple has defended its feature as a means to enhance user privacy.
- If Apple does not address concerns, it risks daily fines and may face further proceedings.

sources.title: Apple’s app tracking privacy framework could fall foul of German antitrust rules
